subject: Economics
title: Alfred Marshall: Supply, Demand, and the Scissors
description: A micro-lesson that makes Alfred Marshall: Supply, Demand, and the Scissors usable.

hook.text: Before 1890, economists fought: does value come from production cost or buyer desire? Marshall said both.

buildup.text: Marshall drew the supply and demand diagram every economics student learns.

discovery.text: His 'Principles of Economics' textbook dominated for 50 years.

twist.text: Marshall deliberately wrote in plain English and hid the math in footnotes.

climax.text: Every price you pay is the result of Marshall's scissors â€” supply meeting demand at one precise point.

punchline.text: The most important chart in economics fits on a napkin.

quiz.question: What was Alfred Marshall's 'scissors' analogy about?
options: Both supply and demand determine price, like both blades of scissors cut
